title: Show HN: I spent 6 years building a ridiculous wooden pixel display
summary:
After six years of development, the author has launched Kilopixel (kilopx.com), a large, impractical 40x25 (1,000-pixel) wooden display controlled via a web interface, allowing anyone on the internet to draw on it. Inspired by unconventional mirrors and slow eInk displays, the project aims to be the most inefficient display possible.

The development involved numerous prototypes, starting with a wooden gantry system and pivoting to extruded aluminum. A significant challenge was finding suitable pixels, with the author experimenting with various balls (ping pong, Nerf, etc.) before settling on custom-made cubic wooden pixels due to cost, weight, and consistency issues. The author also faced difficulties with mechanisms to turn the pixels initially considering small motors and LEGO wheels.

The final version uses a CNC machine with a custom-built gantry to move to each pixel and a unique "poking" mechanism to rotate the wooden blocks. The system uses a Raspberry Pi to query an API for the next pixel, write the gcode, poke the pixel, and read a light sensor to determine its state.

The web app allows users to submit 40x25 pixel images, vote on submissions, and even collaborate in real-time. The author plans to stream the display on YouTube and create time-lapses of the drawing process and is looking forward to seeing how the internet interacts with the project and has plans to possibly pass the project along.

title: Part 1: A Deep Dive into Rust and C Memory Interoperability
summary:
This article, "Part 1: A Deep Dive into Rust and C Memory Interoperability," explores the complexities of mixing memory allocators between Rust and C. It begins by highlighting the potential dangers of such practices, where incorrect memory deallocation can lead to silent corruption, the worst-case scenario. The author emphasizes the importance of understanding how memory allocators function to avoid unexpected crashes and bugs.

The article then delves into memory fundamentals, explaining concepts like virtual memory, how virtual addresses translate to physical RAM, and the costs associated with memory access. It describes the heap's role in dynamic memory allocation and the challenges of fragmentation. CPU cache architecture, including L1, L2, and L3 caches, is discussed, with a focus on "false sharing" and its negative impact on performance.

A significant portion of the article details the creation of a memory testing laboratory. This framework, built using Rust and C, aims to safely explore allocator interactions by testing multiple allocator implementations, handling crashes, measuring performance, and providing detailed debugging information. The framework uses subprocess isolation, C library loading via FFI, exit code analysis, and performance measurement tools.

Finally, the article introduces four different C allocator implementations used in the testing framework: a standard `malloc` wrapper, a debug allocator for detecting memory corruption, a direct `mmap` allocator for bypassing the heap, and an arena allocator for fast, temporary allocations.

title: Open IP Camera Firmware
summary:
OpenIPC is an open-source, third-party firmware designed to replace the closed-source, often outdated, and insecure firmware found on many IP cameras using ARM and MIPS processors. It provides users with greater control and security over their cameras.

The firmware is distributed as pre-compiled binaries for easy installation, but the full source code is also available under the MIT license, encouraging community contribution and modification. The OpenIPC project uses Buildroot to build its Linux distribution and leverages Majestic, Mini, or Venc stream processors. While Majestic is currently closed-source, the author aims to open-source it in the future with sufficient financial support.

The key benefit of OpenIPC is the freedom it provides. Users gain complete control over their camera and video streams, eliminating concerns about backdoors, malware, or data breaches. The firmware prioritizes core functionality like firmware upgrades and video/audio streaming configuration.

Beyond basic features, OpenIPC supports integrations with IPEYE cloud storage, video streaming to YouTube and Telegram, SOCKS5 proxies, and virtual tunnels. The project also caters to specialized applications such as cameras for drones, construction helmets, medical research, and underwater fishing. The article also mentions a supporters section.

title: Perplexity is using stealth, undeclared crawlers to evade no-crawl directives
summary:
This article from Cloudflare accuses Perplexity, an AI-powered answer engine, of using stealth crawling techniques to bypass website "no-crawl" directives. Cloudflare observed that after Perplexity's declared crawlers (PerplexityBot and Perplexity-User) were blocked using robots.txt and WAF rules, it continued accessing content using an undeclared crawler disguised as a generic Chrome browser. This "stealth crawler" used different IPs and ASNs to evade detection and circumvent blocking efforts.

Cloudflare argues this behavior violates the established internet principle of trust, which demands transparency and adherence to website preferences from crawlers. In contrast, the article praises OpenAI for respecting robots.txt and not attempting to evade blocks.

Cloudflare has responded by de-listing Perplexity as a verified bot and adding rules to its managed system to block this stealth crawling. Existing Cloudflare customers with bot management rules are already protected. The company also provides options for challenging requests from suspicious bots, offering further protection.

The article concludes by emphasizing Cloudflare's commitment to Content Independence Day, which aims to give content creators control over how their content is accessed by AI. Cloudflare is working with technical and policy experts to establish clear principles for well-behaved bot operators and adapt its methods to combat evolving evasion techniques.

title: My Ideal Array Language
summary:
This article outlines the author's vision for an ideal array language, emphasizing the need for languages and compilers to adapt to the increasing heterogeneity of modern hardware. Key features include user-extensible rank polymorphism, value semantics with automatic bufferization, and compiler transparency.

The author argues that rank polymorphism is essential for array languages, allowing users to write their own polymorphic kernels. They highlight the advantages of value semantics and automatic bufferization, drawing parallels to Fortran's ability to generate performant code due to its array semantics. The article delves into MLIR's role in array compilation, particularly the tensor and memref types, showcasing how functional array languages align well with compiler internal representations.

The importance of a compilation step (offline or online) for optimizing based on language semantics is stressed. Compiler transparency and inspectability are deemed crucial, allowing users to understand optimization failures and debug performance issues. The author cites LLVM's remarks framework as a good example, though it's geared towards compiler engineers. Ultimately, the article advocates for an array language that empowers users with control and insight into the compilation process, enabling them to write efficient code optimized for diverse hardware architectures.

summary:
This article discusses the historical practice in Japan of erecting "tsunami stones" as warnings to future generations about the dangers of building near the coast. These stones, some dating back to 1896 after devastating tsunamis, served as reminders to seek higher ground after earthquakes to avoid subsequent waves. The article highlights the stone in Aneyoshi, which explicitly instructs people not to build homes below its location.

Historian Itoko Kitahara emphasizes that these stones are warnings across generations, aiming to prevent future suffering. However, over time, their importance was often disregarded as coastal towns expanded and faith was placed in seawalls. Despite this, some communities, like Aneyoshi, continued to heed the stones' messages, which proved crucial during the 2011 tsunami.

The article also mentions that tsunamis left a mark on place names, indicating safe or dangerous locations. Fumihiko Imamura notes that the memory of disasters tends to fade after three generations, leading to the warnings being forgotten. The article concludes by referencing the ongoing recovery from the 2011 tsunami and the Fukushima Daiichi disaster, underscoring the continued relevance of understanding and respecting the potential dangers of coastal regions.

title: Scientists shine a laser through a human head
summary: Scientists have, for the first time, successfully shone a laser through a human head. This breakthrough, reported by BiomedicalNews, is a crucial first step towards developing a potentially inexpensive new medical imaging technique. Researchers at the University of Glasgow's Extreme Light group achieved this by sending photons from a laser through the skull and brain to a detector on the other side. The visual provided shows a potential path for 50 photons as they travel from the laser (red) to the detector (green). While the article doesn't elaborate on the specifics of the imaging technique, it clearly indicates that the ability to transmit light through the skull is fundamental to its development. The implications of this achievement are significant as it suggests the possibility of a more affordable medical imaging solution compared to existing technologies like MRI or CT scans.

title: Job-seekers are dodging AI interviewers
summary:
This Fortune article explores the growing trend of companies using AI for job interviews and the resulting backlash from job seekers. While HR departments see AI interviewers as a way to efficiently handle large applicant pools and free up time for more meaningful later-stage conversations, many candidates find the experience dehumanizing and ineffective.

Job seekers describe AI interviews as awkward, impersonal, and even a red flag indicating a poor company culture. They express frustration with repetitive questioning, the inability of the AI to answer questions about the company, and the feeling of being undervalued. Some are refusing to participate in AI interviews altogether, preferring to risk continued unemployment rather than subject themselves to the process.

The article highlights contrasting viewpoints: HR professionals emphasize the time-saving benefits and the ability to focus on top candidates, while job seekers lament the lack of human connection and express concerns about the future of work being overly automated.

Despite the negative feedback from job seekers, companies providing AI interview solutions claim their clients are satisfied with the results, suggesting that the technology is here to stay, particularly for initial screening stages. However, even AI proponents acknowledge limitations, particularly in assessing cultural fit, highlighting the continued need for human involvement in the hiring process.

title: GHz spiking neuromorphic photonic chip with in-situ training
summary:
This article, published on arXiv as arXiv:2506.14272, reports a significant advancement in neuromorphic photonic computing. The authors, led by Jinlong Xiang and Xuhan Guo, present a GHz spiking neuromorphic photonic chip with in-situ training capabilities.

The core innovation is a photonic spiking neural network (PSNN) chip built on a silicon platform compatible with complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) technology. This chip emulates brain-like function through gigahertz-scale nonlinear spiking dynamics, in-situ learning with supervised synaptic plasticity, and retina-inspired spike encoding. These features address key challenges in spatiotemporal data integration and energy-efficient dynamic processing.

The PSNN chip achieves frame-free, event-driven operation. The authors demonstrate its capabilities on the KTH video recognition dataset, achieving 80% accuracy while exhibiting processing speeds approximately 100 times faster than traditional frame-based approaches.

This research represents a major step forward for neuromorphic computing, potentially enabling real-time dynamic vision processing and adaptive decision-making in applications such as autonomous vehicles and robotic navigation due to its low latency and high throughput. The paper details the chip's architecture and performance, including 18 pages of content and 4 figures.

title: Microsoft tops $4T in valuation: Great news for MSFT, not so great for workers
summary:
The article discusses Microsoft's recent financial success, reaching a $4 trillion valuation, driven by growth in its cloud and AI businesses. However, this success is juxtaposed with significant layoffs (around 25,000) due to the company's strategic shift towards AI and cost-cutting measures. CEO Satya Nadella acknowledges the "enigma of success" where thriving companies still lay off employees for future progress.

The trend of replacing human workers with AI is not unique to Microsoft. IBM, Meta, Amazon, TCS, and Indeed are all cited as examples of companies reducing their workforce in favor of AI solutions. This has resulted in an estimated 130,000 tech job losses and a decrease in tech job postings.

The article questions the effectiveness of AI in replacing highly skilled workers, particularly in fields like programming. Despite widespread AI tool usage among programmers, trust in AI-generated results is low, as developers spend significant time correcting AI errors. The author argues that while AI can automate repetitive tasks, it's not yet capable of replacing experienced engineers and developers, suggesting this strategy could negatively impact companies in the long run. The article concludes that while the market rewards cost-cutting, relying too heavily on AI at the expense of skilled workers could be detrimental if AI doesn't deliver on its promises.

title: Software needs an "independent auditor"
summary:
Daksh, co-founder of AI code reviewer Greptile, argues that software development, increasingly reliant on AI-generated code, needs independent auditing tools, similar to the financial industry's reliance on independent auditors after the Enron scandal. He draws a parallel between Arthur Andersen's conflict of interest in both auditing and consulting for Enron and the potential conflict if Greptile also generated code.

Daksh explains that Greptile deliberately avoids generating code to maintain impartiality in its code review process. He argues that if Greptile also offered a code generation tool ("GrepIDE"), its ability and willingness to impartially scrutinize code, especially its own, would be compromised. Similar to how financial auditors must be independent to ensure unbiased assessments, code reviewers should be distinct from code generators.

The article highlights that AI coding agents produce unique bugs that humans might miss, such as hallucinated functions or unintentional changes in unrelated files. With the volume of AI-generated code increasing, the need for automated, adversarial review at the pull request stage becomes critical. The core point: An independent AI code reviewer, like Greptile, is crucial to ensuring the quality and reliability of software built with AI.

title: Gigabyte removes PCIe 5.0 support from B650 motherboards in latest BIOS update
summary:
Gigabyte has removed unofficial PCIe 5.0 support from its B650 series motherboards in a recent BIOS update. Some B650 motherboards, particularly those with external clock generators, had been unofficially enabling PCIe 5.0 support on the first PCIe slot intended for graphics cards, even though the B650 chipset is officially only supposed to support PCIe 4.0.

This unofficial support was popular with users who wanted future-proofing or planned to use next-generation PCIe 5.0 GPUs. However, the BIOS update disables this functionality, limiting the first PCIe slot to its officially supported PCIe 4.0 speeds.

The reason for the change is not explicitly stated by Gigabyte in the article. Some speculate it could be due to stability issues, compatibility problems with specific PCIe 5.0 devices, or potential adherence to AMD's specifications. It's also possible that maintaining PCIe 5.0 support on B650 could have presented challenges in terms of power delivery or signal integrity.

While the article doesn't detail which specific B650 models are affected, it implies that it's those that were previously known to unofficially offer PCIe 5.0. Users who have updated their BIOS will no longer have PCIe 5.0 functionality on their first PCIe slot. The impact is primarily on users anticipating using PCIe 5.0 devices on these motherboards.

The ArcGIS Web Application serves as a platform for visualizing and interacting with this spatial data, promoting a greater understanding and appreciation of New Hampshire's historic stone wall network. title: Perfecting anti-aliasing on signed distance functions
summary:
This article explores anti-aliasing techniques for Signed Distance Functions (SDFs), emphasizing that achieving good results is more nuanced than simply applying a `smoothstep` function.

The core idea relies on the SDF's property of having a gradient of length 1, enabling a smooth transition between inside and outside a shape. The article starts with a `linearstep` function for anti-aliasing, controlled by a width parameter `w`. The value of `w` is crucial: for anti-aliasing, it should correspond to the size of a pixel.

The article discusses ways to determine pixel size. In 2D, this can be calculated directly from the resolution. However, in 3D or when applying transformations like perspective, this approach becomes problematic.  The solution is to use numerical derivatives with `fwidth(d)`, which estimates the rate of change of the signed distance (`d`) as seen from the pixel's perspective, thus adapting the anti-aliasing width appropriately.  An alternative is the L2-norm `length(vec2(dFdx(d), dFdy(d)))`, though computationally more expensive.

The article then compares `linearstep` with `smoothstep`, surprisingly concluding that `smoothstep` often yields visually better results, especially with larger blur widths, despite the discontinuity.

Finally, it touches upon the importance of color space, recommending OkLab for blending colors, especially for blurring, although linear blending can suffice for basic anti-aliasing. The article concludes with a few practical code examples combining these techniques for various scenarios.

title: The Revolution of Token-Level Rewards
summary:
Levro, a startup aiming to simplify international commerce with AI agents, encountered challenges training LLMs for complex tasks like technical customer support and structured reasoning. Traditional Reinforcement Learning (RL) methods proved insufficient due to the difficulty of providing specific and nuanced feedback to the model.

The article highlights the limitations of existing RL techniques like GRPO, which assigns a single reward to an entire output, penalizing even partially correct responses. This contrasts with process supervision, which, while aiming for granular feedback, often failed in practice due to difficulty in defining "steps," inconsistent reward model grading, and reward hacking.

Levro developed "Token-Level Rewards" to address these issues. This approach assigns detailed scores to individual tokens based on various quality metrics (e.g., syntax, tool usage, relevance), using a "judge LLM" to identify influential parts of the output. These scores are then distributed to specific tokens and those preceding them, creating "token heatmaps."  Advantages (how much each token helped or hurt the overall score) are calculated independently for each metric and summed, providing precise feedback to the LLM during training.

This targeted training method significantly improved training speed (25%), increased evaluation reward on benchmarks, reduced reward hacking, and improved the model's ability to retain good structure while fixing errors.  The core benefit is more efficient training and higher quality outputs, particularly for complex tasks like code generation and agentic workflows, without requiring extensive compute resources. Token-level rewards transform process supervision into a practical solution that can be used on smaller, more specialized models.

title: The Toyota Corolla of programming
summary:
This article explores the surprising similarities and enduring legacy of PHP and JavaScript, both scripting languages born in 1995 that became cornerstones of web development despite initial design flaws and persistent criticism. The author draws a parallel between PHP and the Toyota Corolla: reliable, affordable, and ubiquitous, powering a significant portion of the web.

The article addresses common criticisms against PHP, acknowledging its quirks and security vulnerabilities, but argues that it has evolved into a modern language with OOP features, functional programming constructs, type checking, a robust package manager, and strong unit testing support. It also highlights efforts to address security concerns and modernize the language.

The author admits to past participation in anti-PHP sentiment but acknowledges its progress and the thriving community surrounding it, driven by the PHP Foundation. A key development discussed is FrankenPHP, a new runtime based on Go, promising simplified containerization and improved execution models.

Despite these advancements, the article anticipates that PHP will continue to face criticism due to its origins and "bazaar" development style. However, the author ultimately defends PHP's enduring value and its crucial role in enabling affordable web hosting and empowering a vast community of developers. The piece concludes by emphasizing the importance of reassessing PHP's current state and acknowledging its significant contributions to the web.

The project's structure includes modules for UI element detection (UIED), HTML generation, image replacement, and mapping. Installation instructions detail cloning the repository, creating a virtual environment, installing dependencies, and configuring the model and API key (Doubao, Qwen, GPT, or Gemini).

The usage workflow involves several steps: initial HTML generation with placeholders, block detection, placeholder detection, UI element detection, mapping alignment, and placeholder replacement. A simple run command (`python main.py`) is also provided for generating the final HTML code. title: Drawafish.com Postmortem: Whoops
summary:
Alden Hallak's postmortem for DrawAFish.com details a security incident on August 3, 2025, where the website was vandalized due to several vulnerabilities. The incident lasted approximately 6 hours, resulting in username slurs and offensive fish being approved while legitimate ones were removed.

The root causes included: a legacy 6-digit admin password (leaked from a past Neopets data breach) being used for testing and forgotten, a username update API lacking authentication, and a JWT not being tied to a specific user. The exposed password allowed malicious users to access admin privileges and make changes.

The recovery involved manually reversing the mod actions using moderation logs and patching the vulnerabilities. Hallak had to fix his faulty Firebase backups to begin restoration. Hackernews user @iceweaselfan44 used the JWT vulnerability to authorize as an admin and remove offensive content, highlighting a silver lining.

Hallak admits to "vibe coding" and prioritizing speed over security, neglecting code reviews, and relying heavily on Copilot without proper oversight. He acknowledges his shortcomings and recognizes the importance of code reviews and thorough documentation. title: Do LLMs identify fonts?
summary:
This article explores whether Large Language Models (LLMs) can accurately identify fonts from images, a task that humans often struggle with and seek help for on websites like dafont.com. The author created a live benchmark using a Python script to scrape dafont.com and prompt LLMs to identify fonts in images that haven't been identified by the community yet. This approach aims to avoid benchmark contamination by testing the models on unseen images.

Two LLMs, GPT-4o-mini and Gemini-2.5-flash-preview-05-20, were evaluated. They were given the image, thread title, and description (if available) to provide context. The models were allowed five guesses per image, and the results were measured using a top-$k$ accuracy metric.

The author found that the performance of both LLMs was "abysmal," suggesting that the task is either too difficult or that the LLMs struggle when evaluated on truly unseen images. Despite this, the author is happy to find a classification task that LLMs aren't yet good at, emphasizing that LLMs are not magic and still have limitations. The implementation involved Python scripts, GitHub Actions, Simon Willison's llm package, and Observable Framework for creating the benchmark dashboard. The live benchmark is hosted on GitHub Pages.

title: Mastercard deflects blame for NSFW games being taken down
summary:
This article discusses Mastercard's response to the removal of NSFW games from Steam and Itch.io, which Valve and Itch.io attributed to pressure from credit card companies. Mastercard denies directly demanding the takedowns, stating it "allows all lawful purchases" and only requires merchants to have controls against illegal activity, specifically illegal adult content.

The article highlights the disconnect between Mastercard's statement and Valve's experience, where Valve stated that payment processors cited Mastercard's Rule 5.12.7 (regarding "illegal or brand-damaging transactions") as the reason for rejecting legal-for-distribution NSFW games. This rule allows Mastercard to deem unacceptable any material that is "patently offensive and lacks serious artistic value."

The article also clarifies Mastercard's operational role: they don't process payments directly but provide the technology and network for transactions, meaning the pressure was likely applied to payment processors and acquiring banks who then communicated the restrictions to Valve and Itch.io. Itch.io suspended Stripe payments for 18+ content, and Valve was informed of the restrictions by their payment processors, who cited Mastercard. Despite Mastercard's denial of direct involvement, Valve maintains that Mastercard's regulations were the catalyst for the NSFW games being deindexed or removed.

The article concludes by suggesting that public pressure can influence these decisions, noting that the removal of the games initially resulted from a public campaign by anti-porn activists.

title: Tesla withheld data, lied, misdirected police to avoid blame in Autopilot crash
summary:
This Electrek article details how Tesla allegedly withheld critical data, lied, and misdirected authorities and plaintiffs in a wrongful death case involving a fatal Autopilot crash in 2019, for which they were found partially liable in 2025. Within minutes of the crash, the Tesla Model S uploaded a comprehensive "collision snapshot" to Tesla's servers, which the company then allegedly concealed.

The article claims Tesla's attorney scripted a limited evidence request for the police, omitting key data like video and Autopilot information. Later, when police attempted to extract data directly from the car's computers, Tesla allegedly staged a "cooperation" event where a technician claimed the data was corrupted. For years, Tesla denied the existence of the collision snapshot until faced with irrefutable forensic evidence.

After a court-ordered forensic analysis, engineers were able to recover the full dataset, which revealed that Autopilot was active, did not issue a warning despite an impending crash, and that Tesla knew the area was a restricted zone for Autosteer.

The plaintiffs argued Tesla was negligent for allowing Autopilot use in unsuitable conditions and for not implementing sufficient driver monitoring. The jury assigned 33% of the blame to Tesla. The author argues that Tesla fans should show empathy to the victim's family and humility, acknowledging that Tesla should bear some responsibility for the crash. The article concludes by asserting that regulators should investigate criminal charges related to the destruction of evidence and impose fines on Tesla.

title: So you want to parse a PDF?
summary:
This article delves into the complexities of parsing PDF files, contrasting the ideal specification with the messy reality encountered in real-world documents.  While the PDF specification outlines a clear process involving locating the version header, xref table, object offsets, and trailer dictionary, practical implementations often deviate significantly.

The author highlights common issues encountered when parsing PDF files: incorrect startxref pointers due to leading "junk" data, pointers pointing to the middle of the xref table, offsets being "close" but not quite right, or the xref table itself being malformed (e.g., missing linebreaks, extra object entries, garbage data). The article notes that even if the startxref pointer is correct, object offsets within the xref table might still be inaccurate. Modified files may have incorrect /Prev pointers in the trailer, hindering the chain of xref table parsing.

A survey of nearly 4000 files revealed a 0.5% failure rate due to these non-compliant files.  Despite these deviations from the specification, most PDF viewers manage to open these files by employing more lenient parsing approaches. The author emphasizes that parsing PDFs is far from straightforward, citing the challenges as just a small sample of the overall difficulty posed by the extensive PDF specification.  In essence, the article cautions against assuming strict adherence to the PDF specification and underscores the need for robust error handling and flexibility in PDF parsing implementations.

title: Every Visual Workflow Tool Is Just Excel for Developers Who Gave Up
summary:
The article argues that visual workflow tools like Zapier and Power Automate are essentially "Excel for developers who've given up," offering a simplified interface that masks underlying complexities and limitations. The author contends that these tools, while seemingly easier, create dependency nightmares akin to sprawling Excel spreadsheets and ultimately make developers less capable.

The author criticizes developers for choosing drag-and-drop interfaces over the power and control of code, citing reasons like imposter syndrome, decision fatigue, and the illusion of speed. They argue that while code allows for version control, testing, and precise error messages, visual tools offer vague error messages and lack the ability to customize integrations.

A key point is the economic inefficiency: developers are paying a premium for these tools when they possess the skills to build superior solutions for free using languages like Python or JavaScript. The author highlights the dangers of vendor lock-in, rate limits, missing integrations, poor error handling, and performance limitations inherent in these platforms.

The article concludes that reliance on visual workflows signifies a cognitive laziness and a willingness to trade developer identity for convenience. It urges developers to recognize their inherent capabilities and choose the power of code over the constraints of visual workflow tools.

title: How we built Blueyâ€™s world
summary:
This article details how Catriona Drummond, lead art director for the first series of Bluey, designed the show's charming and visually appealing scenery, focusing on the creation of the show's backgrounds. Drummond was tasked with showcasing the beauty of Brisbane, Australia, where the show is set.

The process involved gathering extensive reference material, particularly of Queenslander homes, and incorporating key ideas. These included: a graphic representation of space, inspired by local artists like Katy Edwards and Debra Hood; dollhouse-like proportions to enhance the show's cuteness and appeal; and capturing the distinctive color and light of Brisbane, influenced by painters like Jan Jorgensen.

A crucial element was establishing a "shape language," using circles, triangles, and squares to subconsciously communicate character and personality, ultimately settling on rounded rectangles for the world, mirroring the characters.

Finally, Drummond created a "Bluey Bible" for the crew, outlining key rules and guidelines, including: avoiding overly literal dog references; maintaining cute, simplified, and chunky objects; using straight-ahead camera staging; simplifying and flattening space; employing a "reverse" two-point perspective for a wider ground plane; and using colorful, vivid representations of Brisbane's light. The goal was to create something visually delicious and appealing.

title: New quantum state of matter found at interface of exotic materials
summary:
In a groundbreaking discovery, Rutgers-led researchers have identified a new quantum state of matter, a quantum liquid crystal, at the interface of a Weyl semimetal (a conducting material) and spin ice (an insulating magnetic material). The study, published in Science Advances, reveals that under extreme high magnetic fields, the interaction between these two exotic materials creates a unique phenomenon of "electronic anisotropy."

This anisotropy manifests as a directional dependence of electrical conductivity. The material exhibits lowest conductivity in six specific directions within a 360-degree circle. Interestingly, increasing the magnetic field causes electrons to flow suddenly in two opposite directions. This behavior aligns with rotational symmetry breaking, indicating the emergence of a novel quantum phase.

The research team, led by Jak Chakhalian and including Tsung-Chi Wu and Jedediah Pixley, used experimental techniques at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory, which allowed studying these materials at ultra-low temperatures and high magnetic fields. The discovery provides insights into controlling and manipulating material properties, potentially enabling the design of highly sensitive quantum sensors for extreme environments, such as space.

The creation of the Weyl semimetal/spin ice heterostructure was achieved using a specially developed machine called the Q-DiP. The research highlights the potential of combining different materials to explore new quantum phases and expand our understanding of matter beyond the traditional states. It also emphasizes the critical role of collaboration between experimental and theoretical physicists in advancing scientific knowledge.

title: 1981 BASIC adventure game comes to a new platform, the TRS-80 MC-10
summary:
In August 2025, Harry McCracken announced the release of a new port of his 1981 BASIC text adventure game, "Arctic Adventure," to the TRS-80 MC-10 platform, courtesy of Jim Gerrie. The original game was published in a 1981 book but contained a catastrophic bug, rendering it unplayable and leading McCracken to abandon game development.

Forty years later, McCracken rediscovered and repaired the game, adding improvements and making it playable in a web browser. This update received unexpected attention, prompting interest in porting it to other platforms. Jim Gerrie's MC-10 port is the first such adaptation.

The TRS-80 MC-10, a budget computer released in 1983, was chosen for the new port.  It had limited capabilities, but also featured color graphics. Despite its short lifespan, the MC-10 maintains a following among vintage computer enthusiasts.

Gerrie's port is a substantial rewrite that successfully runs the game on the MC-10, eliminating the original game-breaking bug. A few minor changes were made, like replacing references to "Eskimos" with more modern terminology and swapping miles for kilometers. The port is closer to McCracken's original vision of the game than his own updated web version. The browser version includes save and load features for the current browser session. A walkthrough created by Jim Gerrie is also available. McCracken expresses hope that more versions for other emulated platforms will follow.

title: Writing a good design document
summary:
This article provides guidance on writing effective design documents, framing them as proofs aimed at convincing the reader (including the author) that a design is optimal. The author emphasizes the importance of clear organization, comparing poorly structured documents to "spaghetti code." The goal is to guide the reader without surprises, preemptively addressing potential objections and ensuring a straightforward understanding.

Key principles include:

*   **Clarity and Structure:** Organize the document so each point flows logically from the previous one, anticipating reader questions and concerns.
*   **Reader Consideration:** Model the reader's starting knowledge and guide them to understanding the design's value.
*   **Conciseness:** Edit aggressively to remove unnecessary words, respecting the reader's limited attention.
*   **Practice:** Writing many documents is the best way to improve.

The article also provides concrete tips:

*   **Short Paragraphs:** Each paragraph should represent a single idea that can be summarized in one sentence.
*   **Appendices:** Move complex calculations or simulations to appendices, ensuring they don't disrupt the main flow.

The author uses a "worked editing example" to illustrate how to reduce word count without sacrificing information. The article emphasizes that mastering design document writing requires practice and a willingness to receive (and learn from) feedback.

title: AI promised efficiency. Instead, it's making us work harder
summary:
This article argues that AI, despite promises of increased efficiency and freeing up time, is often leading to increased workload, cognitive load, and ultimately, burnout. It challenges the notion that AI automatically translates to higher productivity, citing studies showing developers taking *longer* to complete tasks with AI assistance while simultaneously *thinking* they're faster. The author highlights the paradox of individuals feeling more productive while overall team and organizational performance declines.

The core issue, according to the article, is that AI shifts mental energy from implementation to constant quality control, fact-checking, and prompt engineering, resulting in a new form of cognitive exhaustion.  The article connects this to the broader problem of productivity culture, where the pressure to constantly optimize and adopt new tools mirrors the unhealthy "grind harder" mentality.

The author's recommendations for mitigating these negative effects include reframing productivity to prioritize cognitive energy preservation over time saved, selectively adopting AI tools based on personal experience rather than hype, and acknowledging that AI adoption often involves a temporary productivity dip requiring significant organizational adjustments.  The central point is that we should focus on using AI to create sustainable workflows, rather than just packing more work into the same hours, which can lead to burnout.

title: Qwen Image
summary:
Qwen-Image is a new image generation foundation model from the Qwen series excelling in complex text rendering and precise image editing, especially with Chinese text. Released on August 4, 2025, along with its technical report and weights on Hugging Face and ModelScope, Qwen-Image offers strong general capabilities in both image generation and editing.

The model can be used to generate images from text prompts using the `diffusers` library. Code examples are provided for quick start.

Key features of Qwen-Image include:

*   **High-fidelity text rendering:** Accurately preserves typographic details, layout coherence, and contextual harmony across different languages.
*   **General image generation:** Supports a wide range of artistic styles, from photorealistic to abstract.
*   **Advanced image editing:** Enables style transfer, object manipulation, text editing, and human pose manipulation.
*   **Image understanding capabilities:** Supports object detection, semantic segmentation, depth estimation, novel view synthesis, and super-resolution.

Qwen-Image is licensed under Apache 2.0 and encourages users to cite their work. Despite the release, as of the article content, the model isn't deployed by any Inference Provider.

title: KDE Plasma prepares crackdown on focus-stealing window behavior under Wayland
summary:
KDE Plasma is preparing to enforce stricter focus-stealing prevention under Wayland using the "XDG Activation" protocol, a system designed to prevent unwanted window focus changes. Unlike the flawed X11 system, Wayland requires applications to present a valid, single-use token to the compositor (KWin in this case) to gain focus, ensuring that focus changes are initiated by user interaction.

Currently, KWin has been lenient with applications that improperly use or ignore the XDG Activation protocol, often granting focus to new windows regardless. The upcoming change introduces an "Extreme" setting in Window Management settings that will force KWin to only grant focus if a valid token is presented.

This stricter enforcement has already led to fixes in several KDE components and related libraries, including Dolphin, KRunner, Kickoff, LayerShell-Qt, and Baloo. These fixes ensure that applications correctly request and use activation tokens when launching new instances or opening files. The updates also address issues related to modifier key presses and allow privileged clients to request tokens correctly. The goal is to create a more predictable and secure window management experience under Wayland, eliminating frustrating focus-stealing behavior.

title: Indian Rafale Downed Due to Intel Failure on PL-15 Range
summary:
This article details a reported incident on May 7, 2025, where a Pakistan Air Force (PAF) J-10C reportedly shot down an Indian Air Force (IAF) Rafale using a PL-15 air-to-air missile fired from approximately 200 km. The article, based on a Reuters report, highlights the significance of information superiority, beyond-visual-range (BVR) capabilities, and network-centric warfare in modern air combat.

The key takeaway is that the IAF's intelligence failure regarding the effective range of the PL-15 missile was a crucial factor in the Rafale's loss. Indian aircrews misjudged the engagement distance, believing they were outside the missile's range. The PAF utilized a "Data Link 17" network to fuse data from air, land, and space assets, providing a comprehensive situational awareness advantage.

The article emphasizes that this incident wasn't necessarily a reflection of the Rafale's capabilities, but rather the effectiveness of the PAF's network and the exploitation of intelligence gaps. India has reportedly adapted its tactics and updated equipment following the engagement.

The article also mentions unconfirmed reports of additional losses for the IAF, including Rafales, Su-30MKI and MiG-29, plus potential Chinese support in the form of real-time radar and satellite data to Pakistan. While China and Pakistan deny these assertions, the incident underscores the importance of accurate intelligence, robust networks, and continuous adaptation in modern air warfare.

title: Life, Work, Death and the Peasant: Family Formation
summary:
Bret Devereaux's article "Life, Work, Death and the Peasant: Family Formation" initiates a discussion on marriage patterns within pre-modern peasant societies, highlighting their significance as the cornerstone of everyday life. The piece emphasizes that while high mortality rates remained consistent across cultures, marriage patterns varied significantly.

Devereaux stresses the importance of focusing on the marriage practices of the peasant class (the bottom 90%) and notes the pitfalls of generalizing marriage behaviors from the elite to the common folk. He uses monogamy as a central focal point for simplicity.

The article identifies three marriage patterns based on age at first marriage (AAFM): "early" (females marrying in their early to late teens, with a mean around 16), "middle" (females marrying in their mid-to-late teens, with a mean around 20), and "late." The article specifically notes that this does not mean everyone is single or married at a specific age, but is representing the mean age for all in that society. The author uses examples from ancient Greece (early) and Rome (intermediate) to illustrate these models. In ancient Greece, male marriage tended to be around 30.

Devereaux explains that the need to maintain a high birth rate to offset mortality necessitates controlling fertility either within marriage or by delaying its onset. The author notes that early marriage patterns are often associated with a lack of female agency in arranging marriages, while societies with delayed marriage may see more emphasis on female consent.

title: Why doctors hate their computers (2018)
summary:
In "Why Doctors Hate Their Computers," the author, a surgeon, explores the frustrations and inefficiencies introduced by the widespread adoption of electronic health record (EHR) systems like Epic in hospitals. Despite a massive $1.6 billion investment in upgrading to Epic, intended to streamline healthcare processes, the author and many colleagues find the system burdensome and detrimental to patient care.

The article highlights that doctors now spend more time on computer tasks than with patients, leading to longer workdays and increased burnout rates. The author describes how the software's complexity, redundant data entry requirements, and the "Revenge of the Ancillaries" (where administrative needs overshadow clinical efficiency) contribute to the problem. Dr. Sadoughi, a primary-care physician, exemplifies this struggle, noting that the EHR has made tasks like ordering mammograms or updating patient problem lists significantly more time-consuming and less helpful.

Drawing parallels to a case study of fluid dynamics researchers and their software, the author explains that as software systems grow, they become more bureaucratic and less user-friendly. This leads to frustration and a sense of being controlled by the technology rather than empowered by it. The article concludes by suggesting that while computerization has simplified tasks in many industries, it has paradoxically made the medical profession more cumbersome and stressful, resulting in widespread dissatisfaction with EHR systems.

title: Modern Node.js Patterns
summary:
This article highlights the significant evolution of Node.js into a modern, standards-based development environment. It contrasts older practices with modern patterns, emphasizing improved developer experience, reduced dependencies, and enhanced performance and security.

Key improvements include adopting ES Modules (ESM) with the `node:` prefix for built-in modules, which promotes better tooling and clarity. Top-level `await` simplifies initialization, eliminating the need for wrapper functions.

Node.js now incorporates built-in Web APIs like Fetch and AbortController, reducing reliance on external libraries. A native test runner eliminates the need for third-party testing frameworks.

The article also discusses advanced asynchronous patterns, including efficient error handling with `async/await`, and the use of AsyncIterators for event-driven programming. Stream processing has been enhanced with web standards integration and the `pipeline` function for robust error handling.

Worker threads enable true parallelism for CPU-intensive tasks, while built-in watch mode and environment file support streamline the development process. Finally, the article touches on enhanced security features like the permission model and built-in performance monitoring, along with easier application distribution through single executable applications. Overall, modern Node.js embraces web standards, provides better tools, and fosters a more efficient and secure development workflow.

title: America Should Assume the Worst About AI
summary:
In "America Should Assume the Worst About AI," Matan Chorev and Joel Predd argue that the rapid advancement of AI, particularly the potential for Artificial General Intelligence (AGI), poses significant and unpredictable national security challenges that Washington must proactively address. They contend that policymakers need to prepare for disruptive events driven by AI, like a U.S. or Chinese company claiming AGI breakthrough or AI-enabled cyberattacks, instead of being caught off guard like with past geopolitical shifts.

The authors emphasize that the U.S. needs to enhance its understanding of the global AI ecosystem, fostering public-private partnerships to navigate AI's challenges, and develop policies for sharing sensitive information with allies. They highlight the potential for AI-enabled cyberattacks that are hard to attribute and could be carried out by autonomous AI agents, necessitating enhanced cyber defenses and international coordination.

Chorev and Predd suggest a multi-pronged approach: establishing "no regret" actions, creating adaptable "break glass" playbooks for emergencies, investing in crucial capabilities across scenarios, and prioritizing early indicators of strategic failure. They warn against treating AGI as a "normal technology" or "normal scenario," advocating for broad governmental involvement beyond traditional national security agencies. They also emphasize the importance of considering how AGI might reshape the international landscape and global power dynamics, advocating for early planning with allies and partners in a multipolar world. The article concludes that failing to plan for AGI's transformative effects will render any national security strategy irrelevant.

The paper's ambitious goals, like reaching 200 million subscribers, are met with skepticism, as are initiatives such as a "third newsroom" for commercial ventures and an AI-assisted opinion platform.

While the Post faces challenges common to the media industry, like attracting subscribers and navigating the content-creator landscape, the departures are also driven by individual career aspirations and a desire for independence. The article acknowledges the Post's remaining talent while questioning its long-term strategy and direction. As a result, the author predicts a decline in Python adoption for production deployments within companies. While some might argue this trend existed before AI, the author believes the impact is amplified by these tools.

title: Rising young worker despair in the United States
summary:
This working paper by David G. Blanchflower and Alex Bryson investigates the changing relationship between mental despair and age in the United States from the early 1990s to 2023. Historically, mental despair followed a hump-shaped pattern, peaking in middle age. However, the study reveals that this pattern has shifted to a monotonic decline with age, indicating a significant increase in despair among young people.

The study highlights that this shift is primarily driven by rising despair among young *workers*. While the traditional hump-shaped pattern persists for those unable to work and the unemployed, and a flat relationship is observed for homemakers, students, and retirees, the increased despair among young workers is the key driver behind the overall change in the age-despair profile.

The authors used data from various sources, including the Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS), the National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH), and surveys by Pew, the Conference Board, and Johns Hopkins University, to support their findings. These datasets provide broad-based evidence that mental despair has increased among young workers over time, leading to a more pronounced downward-sloping relationship between age and mental despair within the working population.

title: Read your code
summary:
This article emphasizes the critical importance of reading and understanding AI-generated code, even with advanced tools like Claude Code and Windsurf. While "vibe-coding" (dialogue-based coding with AI) offers speed and efficiency, neglecting code review presents significant risks:

*   **Weakened Architecture:** Unreviewed code can introduce inconsistencies and drift from established patterns, leading to a breakdown of the overall architecture.
*   **Loss of Implementation Knowledge:** Over-reliance on AI without understanding the underlying code can diminish a developer's domain expertise and hinder creative problem-solving outside of coding.
*   **Security Vulnerabilities:** AI may overlook crucial security considerations like access control, potentially introducing vulnerabilities that could lead to breaches.

The article proposes two approaches to responsible vibe-coding:

1.  **Fast Prototyping with Auto-Accept Mode:** Suitable for peripheral features or exploring new technologies, allowing AI to run more independently, followed by a comprehensive review.
2.  **Synchronous Coding for Core Features:** Involves close supervision and iterative acceptance of AI suggestions, enabling continuous course correction and ensuring architectural consistency.

A "Vibe-Coding Checklist" is provided to guide code review, covering architecture, security, testing, documentation, error handling, and performance. The central message is that AI coding assistants are tools to amplify expertise, not replace it. Maintaining mastery of the codebase is crucial for long-term innovation and preventing architectural decay. Teams should not eliminate code reviews based on the assumption that AI provides sufficient quality assurance.

title: A dedicated skin-to-brain circuit for cool sensation in mice
summary:
A University of Michigan study has identified a dedicated neural circuit that transmits cool sensations from the skin to the brain in mice. This is the first fully mapped pathway for temperature sensation, revealing that cool temperatures have their own distinct circuit, separate from hot temperatures.

The pathway begins with molecule sensors in the skin that detect cool temperatures (15-25Â°C). These sensors activate primary sensory neurons, which relay the signal to the spinal cord. Surprisingly, the signal is amplified in the spinal cord by specialized interneurons before being sent to projection neurons that connect to the brain. Researchers found that disabling this "amplifier" renders the cool signal undetectable.

While the study was conducted in mice, genetic sequencing indicates that humans possess the same circuit. This discovery has potential medical implications, particularly for understanding and treating cold-related pain, such as that experienced by chemotherapy patients. While the newly mapped circuit doesn't mediate this type of pain, understanding its normal function could help researchers identify what goes wrong in disease or injury and develop targeted therapies. Future research will focus on identifying pathways involved in acute cold pain and how the brain processes various skin signals and associates them with emotions.

title: C++: "model of the hardware" vs. "model of the compiler" (2018)
summary:
"No Bugs" Hare critiques a proposed amendment ([P1063R0]) to Bjarne Stroustrup's definition of C++. Stroustrup states C++ provides a "direct and efficient model of hardware combined with facilities for defining lightweight and efficient abstractions." [P1063R0] suggests changing "model of hardware" to "model of the platform," arguing templates map the *compiler's* code generation facilities, not hardware.

Hare strongly disagrees, arguing this shifts the focus from a "model of the hardware" to a "model of the compiler," which he sees as a fundamental mistake. He contends a programming language's purpose is to translate human-expressed programs into instructions hardware can understand. The only interfaces should be between humans and the language, and the language and the hardware. Compiler internals are implementation details that shouldn't be exposed or considered when defining the language.

He argues focusing on the compiler's model can justify arbitrary design choices with no relation to real-world requirements. Hare suggests that templates are valuable not because they map compiler facilities, but because they simplify programming for humans by allowing for generalized algorithms.

Hare fears that using "model of the compiler" as a justification opens the door to over-specifying the language and exposing internal implementation details to programmers, which he believes is a dangerous path for C++. He concludes by emphasizing the risk of justifying features based on compiler implementation details, potentially harming the language's overall design.

title: Eating ultra-processed foods could make it harder to lose weight
summary:
This Nature article discusses a study published in Nature Medicine that suggests consuming ultra-processed foods (UPFs) may hinder weight loss efforts, even when following recommended dietary guidelines. The study compared the effects of an 8-week diet based on minimally processed foods (MPFs) and an 8-week diet based on UPFs, both adhering to UK national dietary guidelines.

Researchers found that participants lost significantly more weight (1.84 kg vs. 0.88 kg) and experienced positive changes in body composition, such as decreased fat mass, on the MPF diet compared to the UPF diet. Cravings were also reduced during the MPF phase.

The article emphasizes the potential lack of focus on UPFs in national dietary recommendations despite their high consumption in countries like the UK, Europe, and the US.  It also highlights the socio-economic implications, suggesting that the affordability and accessibility of UPFs disproportionately affect low-income populations, potentially setting them up for dietary failure despite their intentions to eat healthily.  The study calls for a greater understanding of the impact of UPFs on diet and health and consideration in dietary guidelines.

title: Anatoli Bugorski, Soviet scientist proton beam passing through his head survivor
summary:
Anatoli Bugorski, a Russian particle physicist born in 1942, is notable for surviving a radiation accident in 1978. While working at the Institute for High Energy Physics in Protvino, he accidentally leaned into the path of a 76 GeV proton beam from the U-70 synchrotron. The beam passed through his head, delivering an estimated dose of 2,000 to 3,000 Sieverts.

Despite the extremely high radiation exposure, Bugorski survived, defying doctors' expectations. Initially, the left side of his face swelled and the skin peeled away, revealing the path of the proton beam. While there was no significant damage to his intellectual capacity, he experienced increased mental fatigue. He lost hearing in his left ear and the left side of his face became paralyzed, though this paralysis prevented aging on that side. He also experiences occasional seizures.

Bugorski continued working as a physicist, even becoming the experiment coordinator for the same accelerator. Due to Soviet secrecy policies, he remained silent about the accident for over a decade. He regularly attended a Moscow radiation clinic. He expressed interest in being studied by Western researchers but lacked the financial means to travel. He is married to Vera Nikolaevna and has a son named Peter.

title: Persona vectors: Monitoring and controlling character traits in language models
summary:
This article introduces "persona vectors," a novel technique for understanding and controlling character traits in language models (LLMs). Researchers at Anthropic identified patterns of neural network activity that correspond to specific personality traits like "evil," "sycophancy," and "hallucination." These "persona vectors" allow for:

*   **Monitoring:** Tracking personality shifts in LLMs during conversations or training, helping to detect drift toward undesirable traits.
*   **Mitigation:** Intervening during training to prevent models from acquiring unwanted personalities. The counterintuitive method involves "vaccinating" the model by steering it towards the undesirable persona, making it more resilient to harmful training data.
*   **Identification:** Flagging problematic training data likely to induce unwanted traits by analyzing how it activates persona vectors. This allows for curating datasets to avoid negative personality development.

The method is automated, requiring only a definition of the target trait. Validation involves "steering" the model by artificially injecting persona vectors, demonstrating a causal link between the vector and the expressed trait. Experiments on open-source models (Qwen and Llama) showed the effectiveness of these applications. The article concludes that persona vectors offer a promising approach to ensuring LLMs remain aligned with human values by providing insights into how models acquire and express different behavioral characteristics.

title: Efficiently Generating a Number in a Range (2018)
summary:
This article explores the performance overhead of generating random numbers within a specific range, a common task in randomized algorithms, often overshadowing the performance of the underlying pseudo-random number generator (PRNG) itself. It highlights a fictional scenario where a less optimized, but efficiently implemented, PRNG outperforms a faster PRNG because of inefficient range generation.

The article reviews various methods for generating random numbers in the range [0..k), focusing on C++ implementations. These include:

*   **C++ Built-in:** Utilizes `std::uniform_int_distribution`, often over-engineered and not the most efficient.
*   **Classic Modulo:** Simple but slow and biased due to the division operation and unequal distribution of remainders.
*   **FP Multiply:** Converts PRNG output to a floating-point number in [0..1) and scales, biased and less portable to 64-bit.
*   **Integer Multiplication:** Uses fixed-point arithmetic, faster but biased.
*   **Division with Rejection:** Unbiased but slow due to division operations and rejection loops.
*   **Debiased Modulo (Twice):** OpenBSD's method, eliminates bias with two modulo operations, slower than the classic method.
*   **Debiased Modulo (Once):** Java's method, uses one modulo operation, with rejection performed occasionally.
*   **Debiased Integer Multiplication:** Lemire's method, removes bias from integer multiplication.
*   **Bitmask with Rejection:** Apple's method, uses masking to get a number in the range, rejecting if the result is too large.

The article then introduces a "Large-Shuffle Benchmark" and tests different methods, including 32-bit and 64-bit implementations. The key takeaway is that the method used for generating a number within a range significantly impacts performance, and even a slower PRNG can lead to faster overall performance if the range generation is optimized. The article stresses the importance of benchmarking to determine the best approach for a specific use case.

title: If you're remote, ramble
summary:
This article advocates for creating personal "ramblings" channels within a remote team's chat app to foster social cohesion and idea generation. Designed for teams of 2-10 people, these channels act as individual microblogs or journals where team members can share thoughts, ideas, and updates without disrupting group channels.

The suggested format involves each team member having a channel named after them, where only they can initiate new posts. Others can reply in threads. Channels should be grouped in a dedicated "Ramblings" section, muted by default, with no expectation of being read.

The author shares their experience at Obsidian, where "ramblings" have become a successful alternative to water cooler conversations in the absence of scheduled meetings. They promote deep focus time while maintaining connection.

The benefits include surfacing creative ideas, prototypes, and solutions, as well as keeping the human connection alive between in-person meetups. The loose, unstructured nature of these channels allows for free-flowing thought and unexpected insights. Ultimately, "ramblings" offer a lightweight and effective way to improve communication and collaboration within a remote team.

title: This Old SGI: notes and memoirs on the Silicon Graphics 4D series (1996)

title: Over 10k hotels join mass claim against Booking.com
summary:
Over 10,000 European hotels have joined a class action lawsuit against Booking.com, seeking compensation for damages allegedly caused by the platform's past practices of preventing hotels from offering lower prices elsewhere. The lawsuit, filed by Hotrec, the European hospitality industry association, claims these "parity clauses" violated European regulations and resulted in unfair terms and excessive costs for hotels.

Meanwhile, in the Netherlands, the Consumentenbond is preparing a mass claim on behalf of consumers impacted by potentially inflated prices due to Booking.com's policies.

Booking.com denies the claims, stating they are based on an incorrect interpretation of previous rulings and that their actions did not artificially inflate prices. They argue that the restrictions were not inherently anti-competitive under EU law. Despite this, the company has abandoned the disputed policy in Europe, as parity clauses are now prohibited under the European Digital Markets Act, a law designed to limit the power of dominant digital platforms. Booking.com intends to oppose the lawsuits if they proceed to court.

title: Lightning on Earth is sparked by a powerful chain reaction from outer space
summary:
This article explores the long-standing mystery of how lightning strikes are initiated, presenting a new study suggesting that cosmic rays from outer space play a crucial role. While the electrical nature of lightning has been known for centuries, the exact mechanism by which storm clouds generate the necessary electric field has remained elusive.

The study, using computer models and data from various sources, supports the theory that cosmic rays trigger a chain reaction that leads to lightning. High-energy protons from sources like the sun and supernovas strike the upper atmosphere, creating electrons that accelerate along electric-field lines within storm clouds. This acceleration causes the electrons to multiply as they collide with atmospheric molecules like nitrogen and oxygen, resulting in an electron avalanche.

This avalanche produces high-energy photons, including X-rays and gamma-rays, which the model explains often precede lightning strikes. The X-rays, in turn, create more "seed" electrons via the photoelectric effect, amplifying the avalanche. This chain reaction can occur in small areas with varying strength, explaining why some gamma-ray flashes emerge from seemingly dim and radio-silent regions.

The research, led by Victor Pasko, provides a "precise, quantitative explanation" for lightning initiation, connecting X-rays, electric fields, and electron avalanches. This study offers a compelling explanation for how cosmic rays contribute to the powerful electrical discharges observed as lightning.

title: Nonogram: Complexity of Inference and Phase Transition Behavior
summary:
This arXiv article, titled "Nonogram: Complexity of Inference and Phase Transition Behavior," by Aaron Foote and Danny Krizanc, explores the computational complexity of Nonogram puzzles. While the problem of determining *if a solution exists* for a Nonogram is known to be computationally hard, the authors investigate the complexity of the *inference problem* â€“ determining puzzle parameters that can be logically deduced without guessing.

The research aims to reconcile the apparent contradiction of Nonogram's inherent difficulty with its popularity among human players. The key findings are:

1.  **Complexity Analysis of Inference:** The study analyzes the computational complexity of the inference problem in Nonograms.
2.  **Phase Transition Behavior:** The research experimentally demonstrates the existence of a phase transition in the inference problem's difficulty. Specifically, the difficulty is highly influenced by the *density of filled cells (positive parameters)* within the puzzle.

To facilitate their experiments, the authors developed an efficient method for encoding Nonogram boards as Boolean formulas in Conjunctive Normal Form (CNF) using regular expressions. This encoding enables the use of SAT solvers for analyzing the inference problem. In conclusion, the research connects the difficulty of solving Nonograms to the density of filled cells, providing insights into why humans can often solve them despite their theoretical complexity.

summary:
The author rants about the unnecessary and often counterproductive noises made by everyday objects. His frustration stems from his car's loud LPG tank warning, which he finds startling and distracting while driving, ironically jeopardizing safety. He criticizes the lack of configurability and the repetition of the alarm.

He extends his complaint to other appliances, specifically his washing machine and dryer. He's annoyed by the loud, short alarm on the washing machine and the inability to disable the beep accompanying button presses. The dryer also has an unavoidable alarm. He argues that these noises, especially for non-critical events, are intrusive and pointless.

The author also highlights his hotplates' excessive alarm triggered by objects on the touch-sensitive controls. He proposes alternative solutions like blinking lights or automatic shut-off.

The most egregious example, in his opinion, is a baby monitor that beeps loudly when turned on, defeating its primary purpose of silently monitoring a sleeping child.

He contrasts these problematic devices with appliances that are silent or have useful, subtle notifications, such as his dishwasher, fridge, and ebook reader.

The author concludes by imploring designers to prioritize quiet functionality and consider the impact of notifications on sleep-deprived individuals and sleeping children. He laments the need to add "silent operation" to his shopping criteria.

title: Micron rolls out 276-layer SSD trio for speed, scale, and stability
summary:
Micron has announced three new SSDs leveraging their 276-layer 3D NAND technology, each targeting a distinct market segment. The 9650 is a high-performance PCIe Gen 6 SSD using TLC flash, aimed at accelerating AI training and inference. It comes in Pro (read-optimized) and Max (mixed-use) variants with capacities ranging from 6.4 TB to 30.72 TB. Key specs include up to 5.5 million random read IOPS and 28 GBps sequential read bandwidth.

The 6600 ION is a high-capacity PCIe Gen 5 drive, reaching up to 122.88 TB, that uses QLC flash for maximum storage density. It offers higher random read IOPS than its predecessor but lower random write IOPS. A larger 245 TB version is planned for 2026.

Finally, the 7600 is a PCIe Gen 5 TLC SSD designed for consistent low latency, positioned for AI, databases, and cloud computing. It comes in Pro and Max versions with capacities between 1.6 TB and 15.36 TB. All three SSDs incorporate Micron's DRAM, NAND, controller, and firmware, and feature robust security options. The 9650 and 7600 samples are currently shipping, while the 122 TB 6600 ION samples will ship in Q3 2025.
